reviewText:
One time when I was a small child about 8yrs old, my father took me to an amusement park. At this amusment park there was one of those game stands. How you beat this certain game was by throwing a ball into a bucket slightly tilted downward. Simple right? Sure, simple, and by simple I mean the biggest ♥♥♥♥en scam I've ever seen in my life. I spent my entire years allowance on this game which amounted to 20$ (Which is like 1000$ in the hands of a 8yr old) and every time i missed and it would make me extremly angry. I cried, i threw a fit, I was not a happy child. That game changed me when i was 8, I would stay awake at night thinking of different ways to throw the ball and every year I would come back to try the same game again, but everytime I failed.

After a while i figured it was hopeless and i would never play that game again because it was the hardest thing i ever had to do at such a young age.

*9years later*

I get on steam and go to my library and there lay the game Insurgency, a game i bought a year ago just for the sake of it being on sale.

*Launch Game*

One time when I was a teen about 17yrs old, I logged myself into my steam account. In this steam account there were many games, this game was an FPS that resembled any other multiplayer FPS. How you beat this certain game was by killing everyone while constantly being shot at from every single ♥♥♥♥ing direction while your team yells at you. Simple right? Sure, simple, and by simple I mean the hardest ♥♥♥♥en multiplayer FPS I've ever played in my life. I spent my entire years allowance on this game which amounted to 10$ (Which is like 100,000$ in the hands of a 17yr old) and every time i didn't destroy an objective or got shot the second i left the spawn point it made me angrier. I cried, i threw a fit, I was not a happy teen. That game changed me when i was 17, I would stay awake at nigh thinking of different ways to aim or take an objective every day I would come back to try again, but everytime I failed.

After a while i figured i was hopeless and i would never play that game again because it was the hardest thing i ever had to do at such a young age.
Rip:(

reviewText:
Insurgency - sounds quite like a clichée shooter name doesn't it? It actually isn't, as the game proves it's stable and well-working engine. Let's start off with a list of good things about the game!
+ Very complex and smart level design, keeping you edgy in the Modern-War set game
+ A good amount of arcade and realism aspects keep you entertained with a good variety of weapon customizations
+ Extended controls allow you to Arma-like use realistic movements that can help you out in many situations
+ No need to play hundreds of hours to unlock each and every attachment; grinding doesn't exist in this game and makes it a very methodical and fair way to tweak your guns

Gameplay-wise, the realism-style weaponry ranges from modern tactical Iraq-War gear, up until the classic good old WW Mosin Nagant. Insurgency offers you a variety of realism, arcade gamemodes and an overall nice feeling, which keeps you edgy with a very smart level design and clear sound design. Gunplay gives you a good amount of fun balanced with skill. Nobody's perfect, and neither Insurgency; so here are some quite game-breaking flaws:

- Headshots give you a 100% 1hit kill chance, making some weapons very overpowered
- A lacking good AI in singleplayer doesn't make this the best game to play by yourself
- Sadly, like most shooters; odd hitboxes can probably cause you to be very angry; so be warned.
- Unbalanced health/damage system, very COD-like you may die because someone shot you in the ankle. Twice.

I'd like to keep it short, so here's the conclusion about Insurgency:

Overall, it impresses me how unpopular" Insurgency is

reviewText: Only 1 hr into the game and you already know it´s high quality. The aiming is extremely smooth and accurate. The controls are simple, the weapon models are sexy, the connections are great, the optimization and graphics are good too. The realism comes close to Red Orchestra 2, but there sometimes is even more tension than in Red Orchestra which surprised me. Especially close quarters is a tensionride for itself. Sniping is balanced and feels very natural. Feedback is great and recoil as well. Shotguns aren´t overpowered but are realistic and hella lot fun to play and overall even the weaker weapons are accurate and feel very realistic. Insurgency makes everything right, from customization and layout to HUD, balancing and especially fun. I knifed two people, I sniped three in a row while they were moving, I was the hero of the round several times and that good old Counter - Strike feeling was there again. Just like in Red Orchestra, some of the best gaming experiences and memories you possibly could have happen! Precum alert!

reviewText:
Insurgency started as a Source Engine mod, and it evolved through much iteration to finally become what it was always meant to be, a full indie game.

The combat is tight and solid, the weapons look, feel and sound great, and thanks to the many features like being suppressed under heavy fire, or the dozens of weapon attachments and modifications, the game offers an ample and varied close quarter combat experience.
When under fire, the stress induced by the particle effects and the bullet cracking and ricochets around you is something to behold, it really creates a feeling of fear and panic.

Aside from the very solid PVP modes, the game also offers Coop modes, which allows up to 8 friends to play online against AI controlled enemies, and I must say I haven’t had so much fun since the old Rainbow Six “Terrorist Hunt” modes.

Finally a game that scratches my tactical close quarter combat itch, and it scratches it good.

reviewText:
Insurgency. Where to start with what i think is an absolutely amazing game?

Starting out as only a mod this game has come far in my opinion.

Insurgency offers tactical team-based shooting missions and fights to its players. With a wide variety of balanced maps; and an even wider range of weapons with various attachtments to fit your playstyle. Insurgency is the perfect game for you if your into fast paced tactical and action filled fights.

One thing which i think seperates Insurgency from any other FPS is it's realism. Motion blur, wounds, body hotspots, i could go on! You ever wanted a game where you can storm the enemy lines, sliding and ducking for cover, luckily dodging bullets and winning the game for your team? Or maybe you want to lay back with a LMG and suppress your enemies, providing backup to your allies and team members and winning their favour? Well, let me tell you. This. Game. Is. That!

Before i go into more detail i'll tell you why i love Insurgency over games such as Call of Duty. As many of the fellow FPS gaming community knows, some FPS's unbalance the way they work. Some involve vehicles which makes not being in a vehicle a massive disadvantage to playing. Other games simply are played by running around spraying bullets everywhere until a kill is obtained. Well not Insurgency. In this game there are no vehicles, and running in the open carelessly will get you killed. This game is balanced in that sense, it's as easy to die as it is easy to kill someone. A few shots and you're dead. None of that; I can take a whole magazine of SMG rounds to my chest and walk it off" nonsense. So overall it's the balancing which attracts me to Insurgency.

When i first started playing Insurgency i admit i was bad and it was a hard game. But unlike others this didn't throw me off. Any good gamer knows practise makes perfect. The more i played
date: the better i got. You may also find this game very hard if you're used to Call of Duty or Battlefield. So take my word when i say don't run around. Take cover

reviewText:
Insurgency is easily one of the best Tactical Multiplayer FPS's I have ever played.

The realistic and unforgiving combat immerses you into the most gritty and adrenaline fueled combat situations you could ever get into in a game, brought to you by New World Interactive.

There are two teams to a map: Security and Insurgents. Security uses mostly military grade weapons (M16's, mk18's... anything you would expect to see the American army use), while Insurgents use mostly old Russian weaponry (AKM's, SKS's and FAL's). Each team has two squads, each with 8 roles to pick. The point system in the game balances out the amount of attachments and armor you can pick, giving you the choice to either deck out your gun with fore-grips and weapon sights and run un-armored, or armor yourself up and give yourself extra ammo with no optics or attachments on your gun. Most primary weapons are a one shot kill to the torso and head at all ranges which forces you to pick your cover and pathing to the objective carefully.

There are 6 game modes for multiplayer: Skirmish, Push, Firefight, Ambush, Occupy and Strike. Skirmish and Firefight are objective zone based; go to the objective and occupy it until your team has captured it and eliminate all enemy players until their respawn waves are ceased, capturing an objective gives you a respawn wave. The only difference between Skirmish and Firefight is that Skirmish has an addition 2 objectives which can be destroyed. In Push one team needs to hold back the enemy from capturing the two objectives in each zone until their respawn waves run out. Occupy is the classic King of the Hill, Ambush is a VIP escort mission and in Strike you must destroy the enemies objective while you protect your own. Servers can hold up to 32 players (16 per team) and there is an addition co-op game mode.

Overall Insurgency is a tense, strategic and realistic game, brought to you by a small and intuitive game studio that will give you endless hours of fun.

Pros- Well structured maps that suit every game mode,
Extremely polished weapon models and weapon animations,
Limited Heads Up Display,
Harsh damage model/ Health System.

Cons- Movement animations are a bit On rails"
date: \nand Bullet ballistics are simple and outdated."

reviewText:
Since this game originally appeared here, it has had many changes. Over the years, I've always been a huge fan of the immersiveness that this game provides, of the realistic sounds (you can hear the echos and dinks!), and of the great community that surrounds it. Only one thing had stopped me from becoming the gamerest gamer of this game, and it was the inability to play it natively on Linux. I did run it in Wine without much trouble, but it still had some issues with the soundsystem, and in the end I opted to just dualboot for gaming purposes. About a month ago, I managed to destroy my Windows partition, and now have only Linux.

For a long, long time, I would open my Steam Library and almost poop my pants whenever I saw Insurgency on the top of the list (favourite games tab). Up until today it had always been a disappointment - the Library showing all owned games as opposed to only those that run on Linux. But today... Today it happened for real. I cannot express the happiness. I checed three times to make sure it wasn't some sort of strange glitch. Now, I'm downloading the game.

Thank you, devs. If it matters at all, you just made a grad student a lot happier :)

reviewText:
A tactical masterpiece!

While the game looks like a normal first-person-shooter at first, it has a very unique feel to it once you actually play it.

A new level of immersionIf you value realism, you will love this game. Everything is built to bring an immersive feeling to the player and the game does that successfully. The weapons feel like real weapons while moving, aiming and shooting. The maps look realistic and detailed. Only the sounds are not optimal and don't feel right for some weapons. Something the developers should keep and ear on.

Addictive tactical gameplayThis game is nothing like the purely action-based and fast shooters like Call of Duty, but it is also even slower and more tactical than Counter-Strike, yet faster than tactical simulators like ArmA or Americas Army, while still maintaining all tactical elements. It feels like it takes that perfect line between tactics and action and once you get used to it, it becomes really addictive. Although it may be initially frustrating for some, if they are used to fast shooters.

Huge potential for skillAn important factor for competitive players: Skill really matters and can make a huge difference. Although this is a different type of skill than in games like Counter-Strike, which is heavy on aiming and hitting. The actual killing in Insurgency is not too difficult, as people die from just a few hits after they get spotted. But what the focus lies on in this game is the right positioning, movement and teamplay to actual get the advantage over your opponents. Outplaying comes more from the mind in this game.

Competitiveness is rather poorDespite having all that potential for it, the game is not making much use of the competitiveness. Currently there is no real matchmaking with team balance and competitive matches. The competitive scene is pretty much not existent. The developers are rather implementing more different types of gamemodes to add versatility for casual players, which is totally fine, but they also end up splitting the playerbase too much between these modes. The game is certainly lacking something like a main mode for players to compete between each other.


Those 4 points are the main ones you have to know, if you are wondering if it's worth buying the game.
Overall I would definetly recommend this game for tactic fans. But if you are looking for a game which brings quick and fast paced matches, it is not the right game for you.

reviewText:
It's really surprising.
Insurgency has no flaws. Even to a pessimist.
This challenging shooter is smart, rewarding and, most importantly, utterly impressive. The gameplay design choice to remove most of the HUD and the entire kill feedback altogether was ingenious.
The decision to add the non-zoomed background when looking through the scope, material penetration, a great sound library (Even the non-integral feature of the game the Alackhu Akbar mod that I can't play without) and all the other small details that we will never notice make up the crown jewel of Insurgency.
Oh, and the devs are just great, since they have created good free content. Lots of it. They're really far from the greediness of Overkill and sometimes seem more productive than the devs on Rust.

reviewText:
Insurgency is honestly some of the best fun I've had in a long time. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a hardcore realisitic modern shooter experience. The game is based upon situations that realisitically simulate warefare, gunfights, capturing and seizing objectives - how you do this is entirely based upon the players, however in this game you will need to work as a team in order to be successful. It is rather realisitic and you can die very quickly, so if you're used to fast paced or standard shooters, this game will challenge you.

I personally find it more fun to play with friends who have the game as you can communicate with them more efficiently and really enjoy yourself. Insurgency offers you a small array of training practice to get you used to the game, how it plays, the weapons, etc and it's important to play through the training part as well as have a couple of practice sessions 'till your firm with the gameplay. The game can be taken rather seriously if one wishes too, but honestly, it's brilliant fun!

The only downside I have with this game is that I wish there could be more gamemodes and tactical equipment (For example tripmines/claymores) Apparantly some features are in the original mod version of the game that didn't make it to the purchasable title, but I understand this is most likely for gameplay purposes!

Other than that, a fantastic game inwhich I personally waste hours of entertainment with!

7.5/10

reviewText: After playing the Source mod for a long time back when it first came out, I lost track of it as I moved to other games. This new release, while in a lot of ways less developed and mature than the mod, is surprisingly good. The old maps and weapons we remembered are gone (Can't wait till they bring back the FAL) but the new maps and weapons are brought together in a pretty slick way. It's a tight, focused tactical shooter, not for the impatient run-and-gun style players. I sometimes end up sitting in a spot for minutes at a time, watching my lane and anxiously hoping that my battle buddy upstairs is still alive and alert, only to have a frag thrown into my face and be obliterated before I even get a chance to see the enemy. For something that should be ragequit-inducing, it's actually more suspenseful and fun than one might expect, as being on the delivering end of that quick single shot that takes down an enemy from your firing position or sneakily fragging them before they react seems appreciably more rewarding, knowing that any second can bring you instant death if you're not totally on point and alert. It's not a realism game per se like the Arma series; as a combat vet I can attest that probably nobody outside tip-of-the-spear SOF units can shoot this well, let alone how bad most of the irregular forces were at actual infantry tactics and basic marksmanship. Taken less as an attempt to recreate realistic modern combat in Iraq or Afghanistan, and just as a unique gaming experience, I really enjoy it, but it does need your full attention, as looking away for a second can result in your seeing that old Waiting for Reinforcements" screen until you get your next chance to get it right. I highly recommend this for anyone that liked the old Rainbow Six/Ghost Recon games from the early 2000s
date: and anyone looking to get into a shooter that values patience and team communication and runs at a pace different than the current BF3/MW crop of shooters."

reviewText:
This is very fun game you can shoot things but I'm a short reviewer so I'll leave you with a recipe for pumpkin pie!
=====================================================================================
Serves: 16
For the filling
500g (1 1/4 lb) pumpkin, cooked and pureed
1 (410g) tin evaporated milk
2 eggs, beaten
175g (6 oz) dark brown soft sugar
1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1/2 teaspoon salt

Method
Prep:30min › Cook:1hr10min › Ready in:1hr40min
Preheat oven to 200 C / Gas mark 6.
Halve pumpkin and scoop out seeds and stringy portions. Cut pumpkin into chunks. In a saucepan over medium heat, cover the pumpkin with water and bring to the boil. Reduce heat to low, cover and simmer for 30 minutes or until tender. Drain, cool and remove the peel.
Return pumpkin to the saucepan and mash with a potato masher. Drain well, and measure 500g of the mashed pumpkin; reserve any excess pumpkin for another use.
Prepare pastry by mixing together the flour and salt. Rub butter into flour, and add 1 tablespoon cold water to mixture at a time. Mix and repeat until pastry is moist enough to hold together.
With lightly floured hands, shape pastry into a ball. On a lightly floured board, roll pastry out to barely a .25cm thickness. Transfer to a 20 or 23cm pie dish, gently pressing pastry into the bottom. Cut off any excess pastry hanging over the sides of the dish, and pinch pastry securely around the inner edge.
In a large bowl with mixer speed on medium, beat pumpkin with evaporated milk, eggs, sugar, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg and salt. Mix well. Pour into a prepared pie dish. Bake 40 minutes or until a knife inserted in the centre comes out clean.

reviewText:
Long have I waited for a properly made tactical shooter that I could finally enjoy as much as I did Infiltration, Red Orchestra, SMOD Tactical, and Hostile Intent. I can see myself playing this for years to come. The clunkiness that is present in most games of this genre is nowhere to be found. Animations are top notch, and I will add that they are the most important thing for inspiring immersion. The weapon handling is almost perfect. Perfect enough for its flaws to be of little consequence. I can honestly say this game has the potential to outshine every tactical shooter that currently exists.

Insurgency's controls are quite simple. You've got the usuals, such as aim (iron sights), lean, prone, and sprint. Then there's the extra features that bolster the gameplay. Focus gives you extra zoom and tightens your aim a bit, but only lasts for one breath. Ducking while sprinting allows you to perform a slide. This maneuver is relatively helpful, boosting your speed briefly and allows you to dodge shots or fall into cover. Reloads can be interrupted through several means, such as double-clicking, sprinting, or jumping. Bolt-charging can be delayed by simply holding fire.

There are a range of modes to play, in which, you'll most likely find one you love and stick with it. All modes, versus or coop, are objective-based which includes wide variations on capture points, cache destruction, and a single mode with a VIP. Aside from 'Occupy', the modes don't intrude on the overall experience and take varying amounts of coordiation. Occupy is the black sheep of the bunch because all strategy and tactics are more or less removed in favor of dogpiling onto the objective. Whether this is fun or not is subjective. I say nay because it contradicts the other modes, much less the 'thinking man' philosophy behind the tactical shooter genre.

I've played many co-op game modes in various hardcore FPS games and Insurgency's take on it certainly holds its own. If versus is not to your liking, you can easily spend all your time in the two co-op modes, which are more than adaquate. The AI, as in most other FPS games, can have its cheap 'aimbot' moments that rob you of well-deserved success. It has many other flaws such as but not limited to: predictibility, brain-farts, superhuman senses, superhuman reflexes, etc. but the experience is nonetheless rewarding and challenging. I'm hoping for the day the AI recieves much-needed polishing that will really help the co-op modes shine.

If you've played any AAA FPS for the past... ever, you'll recognize the all-too-familiar loadout system. You are allowed a certain amount of points to spend and you cannot exceed the maximum carry weight. Each weapon has various 'hard-points' to which you can add one accessory. While it's more flexible than other games that sport a similar system, you're very limited in your choices unless a given server has a higher point minimum, and points can only be obtained by accruement of game rounds.

Insurgency's greatest flaws lie in its cheaply designed weapon balance. Many weapons are far too homogeneous with each other for their own good. Others are so far from what they should be and need to be, that you wonder what the devs were thinking or why they even bothered. The M249, for instance, has the 200 round drums. The implemented disadvantages of this from both a game standpoint and a realistic standpoint are almost non-existent. This is nothing compared to the ridiculously lethal RPG weapons. They're so exagerated they may as well be hand-held nuke launchers from Starship Troopers. What hurts the most is that ballistics are non-existant in firearms. Yes, Insurgency has primitive conical hit-scan. If there's one thing that should be changed, it's this because proper ballistics would add so much to the game, it can't be stressed enough. Even the AI would be improved by consequently leveling out its cheapness at medium and long distances. While the suppression and accuracy systems partially counter-act the exploitation of hit-scan, they also introduce some measure of dice-rolling to firefights, something that absolutely does not belong in a tactical shooter. What a pitty.

At the end of the day, the most important thing is that Insurgency achieves what it strove for. To give an immersive and suspenseful experience, deferring realism and authenticity when necessary to easily maintain a competitive and tactical atmosphere.

reviewText: Insurgency is a great purchase. Solo or with friends (or a dedicated group of strangers) it offers a deep, strategic experience that is both rewarding, as well as challenging.  If you herald realism above all-else, and can stomach it’s sometimes crushing difficulty, Insurgency will keep you occupied for a very long time, indeed.

reviewText:
Realism and more realism.

There are no crosshairs.

If you want a realistic firefight experience this is the game. Adrenaline rushes as bullets fly over your head (the suppression effect that happens on your screen helps alot! Which is something you have to see!)

A unique experience! This isnt like other fps games where you can just get back up after you die so play safe! Ounce a player dies in most game modes the only way for them to spawn back is if a set objective is met like capturing a capture point or blowing up a cache. This is a great concept as it forces players to play more 'realistically' as dying has a penalty and could potentially lose the game. This game favours a tactical approach over mindlessly running around the map killing people. This game is fun withought friends but like most games it's funner with friends so tag along! (just be carefull you dont shoot them!) This game relies on teamwork over lone wolfing unlike other popular fps's. This game has been a unique experience for me.

Ever wanted to get a headshot on someone hiding behind a concrete wall? Well now you can! You can shoot through walls and other objects. You can't shoot through metal.

Graphics are good. Sounds are good. Optimization is good. Gameplay is good. Sound is good. This game is great!

The guns feel solid, satisfying and realistic (to the point where I just feel like shooting it at nothing just to see and hear these yummy effects). All guns are lethal. 1 shot to the head and your gone, 3 shots in the body depending on armor, ammo type, gun etc.
Freedom of movement:Tilting, sliding, proning, jumping, crouching are all features in this game! There is also a weight system which determines how fast you can run. So take all those unwated items such as armor and pistols off so you can be Usain bolt!

WARNING: This game is HARD! This game is very unforgiving... simply crossing the road could get you killed in an instant! In order to survive in Insurgency your full attention is needed. Use your ears to hear the footstep and where the gunshots are coming from. Use your eyes to sp And if your fine with with waiting awhile after you die then this is a game I would highly recommend this game!

Only thing I can complain about is the fact that I can't alt + tab out of the game as it causes the game to freeze. I don't know if i'm the only one with this issue however it is a real turn off for me. And the fact that some games only last a couple of minutes before we have to load another map. (This is purely based on how evenly matched the teams are/ how long it takes to wipe out the enemy team etc.) Some rare games however last longer.

Don't regret buying it at full price. They've gone along way since early access and this game has put my attention to the developers in hopes of many more good games to come!

-Note- Players in NZ and Aus DO PLAY whenever i'm on there are always Aus/NZ dedicated servers with a bunch of players.

reviewText:
Insurgency is a first person realistic and tactical shooter game set in middle east, the conflict between the security forces which i think its a private military faction and middle east insurgent.

First thing first the gameplay of this game is pretty damn good, they give you many weapon, attachment, and equipment option for you to pick. You want to carry an RPG ?? You can ! But because its heavy you can't wear a heavy armor. You need to pick and match your equipment to give the perfect balance for you. The weapon recoil is really realistic and very satisfying, the kick that the weapon give and your mouse movement when you try to control the weapon its just fun factor of its own. All the match objective is like some improvement version of capture the point kind of thing, your objective is either capture A, B, and C point, or hold them. There is no heath system in this game you been shot ? You are dead, you shot someone ? They are dead also. I think 2 bullet in the chest is enough to kill any player. There is no indicator when you killed someone, so you have to make it sure yourself, is the guy that you shot is dead or not.

The graphic and the sound this game have is pretty epic also, i never ever play a game that have this kind of epicness into it, when you shoot something, lets just say a wall, there is some white dust come out of that wall when your bullet hit it, so the more you shoot at something the dustier the battlefield become. The sound.. well.. Lets just say it will scare you and your enemy. When the bullet that the enemy shoot hit the object near you, you will hear some loud noise that will make you duck in fear of dying and vice versa. So, you can give your friend some covering fire because when the enemy is been shot at, they will cower in fear too. the sound is that good. Its really hard to explain it, If you try it you will know what i'm talking about.

Apart from the pvp, this game have some co-op option too, which is more tactical than the pvp one, the mode Is 8 players vs 25 AI. (Note that this is in hardcore mode) You didn't have any friend indicator what so ever, so if you go behind the enemy line and your friend see you from far away, prepared to be killed. You need to actually announced your position to your friend so they didn't mistakenly shoot you.

Well, to conclude my review, this is by far the most realistic and fun first person shooter i have ever played and this is coming from a guy that is already played ArmA 2 and Tom Clancy Rainbow Six: Raven Shield. Recommended !

reviewText: Rating: 8/10\n\nInsurgency is a semi-realistic first person shooter (FPS) focusing on small skirmishes at close quarter battle (CQB) distances (e.g. <100m), fought between Security Forces (i.e. Private Military Companies, or PMCs), and Insurgents. Fierce, attritional fights are conducted to capture and secure streets, narrow corridors, and even individual rooms. The British Army aptly calls this type of warfare FISH and CHIPS"
date: or Fighting in Someone's House and Causing Havoc in People's Streets. The environments range from the rocky desert villages and farm settlements in rural Afghanistan to heavily urbanised areas resembling downtown Fallujah
hoursPlayed: probably due to a matter of good taste.)\n\nAs a refreshing change to the FPS industry
voteText: you can't grind your way to getting superior equipment to get unbalanced equipment. There are no level ups or weapons unlocks. Skill
helpfulPercent: tactics and teamwork are the only things that determine your success. Both sides have access to the expected standard equipment

commentsCount: M249 LMG

column17: M40A1 Sniper Rifle
column18: and AT4 Rocket Launcher. Examples for the Insurgents include: AKM Assault Rifle
column19: AKS-74U Carbine
column20: RPK LMG
column22: RPG-7 Grenade Launcher
column23: and even an antique MP40 (German SMG from the Second World War). Both sides also have access to different attachments such as reflex sights (e.g. Aimpoint RDS
column24: EOTech Holo-Sight
column33: and flashlights.\n\nThere are two main competitive (i.e. PVP) modes
column34: with variants of both types: Push
column35: and Firefight. In Push you have to capture points (e.g. Conquest mode in other games)
column36: which opens up new objectives to capture. You have a limited number of reinforcements (i.e. respawns). When depleted the only way to allow your dead team members to respawn is to successfully capture a point. There are two co-operative modes
column37: both of which can only be played on the PMC side: Push
column38: which almost identical to the competitive mode
column39: and Hunt. In co-op Push you still capture points
column40: but also face waves of enemies in counter-attacks. The number of enemies you'll face in a counter-attack usually outnumbers a full co-op team by 2:1. In Hunt you have no reinforcements and are only told the approximate location of objectives. You'll have to kill all AI enemies
column41: find the weapons cache and destroy it with explosives. For co-op
column42: the greatest issue is the AI. They are unaffected by lighting (e.g. darkness)
column46: and have inhumanly incredible aim and reflexes.\n\nThe game mechanics are somewhat realistic
column47: but with a few problems. Bear in mind many of the game mechanics that are unrealistic are due to limitations in the Source Engine. The player movement is far too fast
column49: and weapons accuracy and recoil are heavily understated. Maximum turning speed is superhumanly fast (e.g. compare Counter-Strike to ARMA 3)
column50: crouching is virtually instantaneous (e.g. Matrix dodge like you're The One)
column54: and the AI on co-op modes have some serious deficiencies. Similar to other Source games
column55: bullets come out from players' eyes
column56: not the barrels of guns. Health is modelled simply as hit points with no bleeding or first aid system
column57: so shots to the arm or leg that would incapacitate you in reality are shrugged off in the game. Frag grenades have an unrealistically low damage radius (e.g. M67 has a 5m kill radius and 15m wound radius
column58: compared to 5m kill radius and 6m wound radius in-game). 12G Buckshot has an effective range of 40m in reality with a tight spread at first
column59: but the effective range in-game is closer to 15m. Somehow
column60: the 12G Buckshot that has no penetration ability in reality is deadly against armoured enemies wherever you hit them. The RPG-7 uses the PG-7VM HEAT grenade
column61: which has virtually no blast radius but creates a deadly shower of debris on impact compared to a blast radius of 6m in-game. The muzzle flash for unsuppressed weapons in-game appear to use real-world cinematic special effects blanks
column62: which produce a flash 10 times bigger and brighter than normal rounds.\n\nBy far the greatest issues are armour that offers unrealistic protection
column64: and no terminal ballistics. There are two types of armour in the game: Light armour (i.e. NIJ Level II Armour)
column65: which offer good protection against pistol calibres only; and Hard armour (i.e. NIJ Level III Armour)
column66: which offers excellent protection against multiple impacts from rounds as powerful as 7.62x51mm NATO (e.g. used in M14 EBR DMR) and virtually unlimited protection against pistol calibres smaller than .45 ACP (e.g. used in UMP-45 SMG). Light armour in-game unrealistically gives you protection against rifle calibres
column67: whilst heavy armour unrealistically gives you very little protection against rifle calibres. At a minimum
column68: Level II armour must protect against 6 rounds of 9x19mm Parabellum FMJ or .357 Magnum JSP
column69: and Level III against 6 rounds of 7.62x51mm NATO FMJ (US National Institute of Justice[www.nij.gov]).\n\nSome of the cheapest hard armour plates you can purchase as a civilian offers protection against several dozen impacts from 5.56x45mm NATO with virtually negligible deformation of the rear of the metal plate. Strangely
column70: the game offers armour piercing (AP) rifle rounds
column71: which are rare for actual militaries
column72: let alone PMCs. Even Insurgents have easy access AP rounds in-game
column73: whereas in reality their rounds are usually made in amateur workshops and have significantly less gunpowder. Their poorly maintained weapons and non-existent quality control means that if insurgents were to use factory-grade munitions or improvised AP rounds
column74: their guns would literally explode from the pressure. There are even AP pistol calibre rounds in-game
column75: which are so rare in reality (because they're so pointless) they're virtually non-existent. Rounds follow a straight trajectory (i.e. no bullet drop)
column76: regardless of whether or at what angle they strike a object (e.g. poles
column77: walls).\n\nEven given the deep realism issues
column78: on the whole the experience is an authentic depiction of the havoc of CQB combat for PMCs in a worst case combat scenario—it's also seriously fun. You can die in an instant and not even know who or what killed you. The only other game that offers such an authentic and realistic CQB experience would be Red Orchestra 2
column79: which is set during the Second World War (and also has its own realism issues)."

reviewText: The map was Revolt, the mode was Firefight, all of my fellow Mujahideen were dead. It was up to me alone to capture an objective in order for them to respawn, so I make it to alpha. The area is full of crates, stacks of bricks and stacks of wood, but soon my Jihad senses are tingling... there is an infidel or two nearby! Armed with my MP40 with suppressor attachment, I stalk my prey, sneaking behind objects, checking my corners... until I see the infidel, but he doesn't see me. Allah has blessed me with the element of surprise, so I quickly fire my suppressed MP40, RAT TAT TAT TAT TAT!! The infidel is dead, but I haven't captured the objective yet, so there's another infidel nearby. I continue to stalk my prey... I find the other infidel, but this one sees me too... but Allah has blessed me with a quick trigger finger and I fire first, RAT TAT TAT TAT TAT!! Then I capture the objective and all my fellow Mujahideen respawn, each of their 72 virgins in heaven will have to wait.\n\nThis is a most excellent FPS, probably the best multiplayer FPS I've ever played and definitely worth the money, especially considering that they add new maps, modes and weapons to the game free of charge (no microtransactions or costly DLC). The game is realistic, yet can still be fast paced. You can run and gun if you want, but nine times out of ten that will just get you killed. The sound effects, gun recoil, and damage are realistic and there's no hip fire crosshairs, so you almost always have to aim down sights to be accurate (unless you're barrel stuffing them). The only complaint I have would the be the extremely annoying ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that like to team kill just to be trolls, but things like that happen with just about every other multiplayer game and they can always be vote kicked from the game.

reviewText:
With triple A shooter’s such as Call of Duty and the Battlefield series being considered the standard for an fps in the genre, Insurgency eloquently bust’s out of the mold. Insurgency takes the typical war zone and adds intensity you rarely see in other titles. Firefights are brief and terrifying and give you a thrill you are unlikely to find anywhere else.

Insurgency is a military shooter that aims to be more on the realistic side of the genre. It creates a more tactical and tense gameplay experience, which might be a draw back for some people. Players will have a low damage threshold, sprinting for extended periods of time will hurt your aim unless you are given a chance to recover.

Insurgency uses a somewhat standard load out system in where you pick your specialty and gear at the start of every match. With an assortment of classes that have unique guns and gadgets, there is sure to be one that fits your play style. You are given a set amount of supply points and each piece of gear costs a price. A standard M9 pistol will run you one point where as a full auto M4A1 carbine will cost you a bit more at three points.

With two factions facing off it opens the game up to a nice bit of variety on each side. The security soldier’s will have reduced prices to body armor and ammo where the insurgents will have access to Molotov cocktails. The obvious difference will also be in the gun selection with AK’s and other lower tech guns on the insurgent side. While the security forces sport a burst or semi M16 and other higher end guns you would suspect.

Now that you have gotten through your team selection, picked a class and loaded up on gear it’s time to really dig in. With objectives being the focal point in every match, it is important to work with your team and not run off hungry for kills. Completing and objective will yield one hundred points where a kill will only grant you ten points. There are decent amount of objective varieties, ranging from capturing points to detonating an enemy’s supply cache or even both of those examples in the same match.

Each match typically starts with people rushing for choke points/hot spots or flank routes. After the first blood has been drawn groups tend to start working toward objectives. The game will either won by the last man standing or whichever team has taken the objectives. When it only takes one or two bullets to end someone people tend to take things a little slow, luckily if an objective is capped when you are dead you will respawn with the rest of the team in a reinforcement wave

Insurgency all in all is a well-rounded game that brings rock solid versus multiplayer, a functional co-op game mode and tons of fun to the fps genre. Whether its heart pounding gun fights or just admiring the little things like gun smoke off of your barrel, Insurgency most likely has what you are looking for.

If you finished reading all of that, I apologize if it is poorly writen, still working on my writing. Hope this helped someone purchase this amazing game.

reviewText: The game has superb gunplay, the action is often rather brutal with engagements being swift. Co-op is also rather fun and has gone from being a tacked on extra to a valid game mode in it's own right. It is also worth noting that the devs are working hard on improving the game and ironing out any creases, the game has changed massively from the pre-release build and development seems to be continuing after release and heading in the right direction.

reviewText:
Game Play:
Insurgency offers top of the line virtual combat experience.  Not many games can match the intensity of a fire-fight than Insurgency.  In many ways I find myself intimidated by the game and often curse out loud or jump when I receive fire.  There are however some issues that I find annoying, for one some of the map assets have bad collision and you end up shooting invisible walls (the rocks on peak in particular).  Another issue is the unneeded wait times between rounds, beginning and end of levels, etc (however this has greatly improved recently).  Overall the game play is one of the most intense experiences I've had in gaming, one of the most challenging, and one of the most unforgiving.  I love it.

Sound/Music:
The weapon sounds are top notch and only add to the experience.  The sound of receiving fire is the most realistic I've ever heard (over Arma, Battlefield, Darkest Hour, and other authentic seeking games).  One thing I feel most games fail to achieve is creating weapon sound effects that produce a feeling that the gun is appropriately powerful-scary, Insurgency does not fail in this regard.  Suppressors work like a charm and sadly most people use them, I'd advise the developers to increase the supply cost of them.

Controls:
In early access I found the controls annoying and had to rebind them I also suffered from mouse sensitivity problems.  There were inconsistencies and I even noticed certain weapon actions were changing my mouse sensitivity.  I haven't had a problem since the game released.  I never use default controls in a game, so I'm used to rebinding them.  My current controls are perfect for me.

Graphics:
Surprisingly I have to say graphics in Insurgency are amazing.  Something about the game's level design allows for much more detail and atmospheric effects than other games on the engine.  Personally I'm very immersed in the game and find the levels in Insurgency very realistically portrayed.  I can't imagine the graphics getting any better on this engine.

Value:
Currently at $15 it's not much a risk.  Really, Insurgency has been a steal from Early Access.  An authentic gamers' must buy! Even if only to support the developers and their future.

Coop Game Play:
Initially the coop was laughable and I felt it posed little chance of future success.  However Coop has come a long way and though it does get dull after a bit, it is a great way to practice and hone in skills and knowledge of the game.

Conclusion:
Highly intense, unforgiving, and immersive.  Insurgency offers what most games don't, an authentic realism shooter that doesn't heed to idiots or lack of skill.  Insurgency leaves itself open, open to teamwork, tactics, (virtual) combat effectiveness, and does so with rigorous intentions.  And thus it has my utmost respect.

reviewText:
I've never played any game for more than 30 hours. My average is maybe 12 hours for a game. I'm on 800+ and still going strong – no intent to stop!

This is a fantastic atmospheric game that puts you in the shoes of mercinaries and insurgents. Getting shot at is scary, going out of cover is sweat inducing and managing to pull your pistol out to kill that one dude is exciting as hell.

Teamwork is key – especially with the 'hardcore' mechanics – but not an absolute necessity (it will help you win, that's for sure). As a bonus, there is a (small) competitive scene!

If that doesn't take your fancy, why not play with teammates to clear out objectives one after the other of AI-controlled ennemies? Hell, if you feel like pwning some other players, why not give a shot at the many gamemodes available? At this price point, there is no way you can regret it. See ya on the battlefield!

reviewText: Pure and Simple not much gimmick just straight up gun on gun. This doesn't try to hard to be the best shooters yet is succeds in it's simplicity. You have a few weapons for each class and few gadegets so not much there, almost any weapon kills one to two shot in the upper body so mistakes are paid for dearly. The maps are pretty large bigger than your average cod map and some are close to them , it also supports more players I believe 24. The weapons have heavy recoil so single fire is adviced or controlled burst is a must. The game focuses on objective gameplay and teamwork pays off comminication helps tons. My only gripe is with the rpg launcher it just feels cheap and overpowered other than that the game is fun and very intense since hardcore mode is always on, no hipfie crossjhair no health bar so no crutches. This is an awesome game although it will not fit the bill for all, think Arma meets COD in a way but closer to the first! this is a must play for any fps fan.

reviewText:
Clearly one of the best games i've ever played in my life.
This fantastic realistic FPS is surely not for inpatient CoD/CS:GO kids, it requires much prudence, consideration, teamwork and forethought.
No crosshair, no HUD, no hit indicators, no radar, no sh*t.
Insurgency is an amazing tactical shooter based on teamwork, patience and skill.
The game has many good features, such as an interesting system of weapon kit customization, a well-balanced multiplayer and an attractive coop with many available different playing mods.
The delevelopers work hard on the game, update it regularly and give a maximum support to players and fans.
Thosands of workshop mods, maps and skins allow you to customize your game as you want it to be.
The game community is very huge and active, you can ask and discuss different questions and problems with nice and open people, sometimes even delevelopers participate in discussions.
All weapons, mods and features are absolutely free, there's no f*cking pay2win" DLC.
To be honest
date: it takes a while to get into the game
recommended: but what did you expect from a realistic shooter?\nI would also mention that sniping in Insurgency is disastrously hard at the beginning
hoursPlayed: as a pretty experienced marksman I had to learn some new things and tactics from Insurgency.\nIt's hard to mention everything but I tried my best
voteText: hope you liked this review and it helped you to make a right decision.\n10/10."

reviewText:
Stays true to 'Modern Infantry Combat' while improving on ALOT of things. SMGs, more DMRs, and a launcher for the Marines has been added, as well as options to customize your weapon to adapt to the current envionment. The attachments are all pretty cool and varied, without being so plentiful as to be overwhelming and redundant. Different ammo types have been added as well like AP rounds which allow you to more effectively cut through cover in order to hit targets hiding behind it, or hollow point rounds which can tear your target to shreds, drastically reducing your time to kill (essential in a game like Insurgency). If you've ever played a modern military shooter, I'm sure I'm not telling you anything new so I'll move on to why you should buy this game.

GAMEPLAY:
This game is like my ex-girlfriend; cold, brutal, and unforgiving. The weapons have ACTUAL recoil, and getting shot once in the chest with most weapons is enough to make you dead over-easy. A well placed machine gunner can decimate a whole team, getting shot behind cover is a common occurence, centering your sights on someone takes about half a second (more than enough time for you to get blasted), when you fire an unsilenced weapon EVERY ONE and their grand mother knows where to find you, and the people you're playing against will more than likely have been playing for close to a decade (seeing as how they're vets of the original mod) and will perpetually butt **** even experinced FPS players until they get it together enough to the point that they realize this isn't COD, BF, or CS.

You will die A LOT. Went through a door first? Dead? Didn't stick with your team mates? Dead. Some one texted you, and you looked away for juuussst a second? Dead. And when you die, you don't just sit at a respawn screen for a few seconds and get back into the fight. You must shamefully sit there and wait until your team mates capture the next objective. Making the shame of dying pointlessly/stupidly that much worse because your team is really depending on YOU to win.

AUDIO:

This game sounds better than anything I've played in a long time. The ambient sound is oddly calming and serene, making it that much more jarring when the staccato of gun fire thunders all around you or the audible *WUMP-BANG* of an RPG explodes and murders your whole squad. I love playing in the mountains and camping just to hear all the different sounds going on around me (Sorry to the people I played with), or even in the city where it honestly SOUNDS like a city. Headphones are definitely recommended to enjoy this game to it's fullest.

VISAULS

Not the best looking game in the world, but still very pretty; especially when the settings are cranked to max. Is this the next Call of Crysis Modern Battlefield Ghosts 3 in terms of graphical fidelity? No, but it definitely holds it's own, especially when you consider this was made by a relatively small team with an even smaller budget.

MAPS

Varied in size, uniform in the acute attention to detail that has been payed to them so that players can have the best experience. I have a few maps that I love, more that I like, and none that I hate. Each time there's a vote for a new map, you really can't go wrong by just picking something random and going with the flow.

CONCLUSION

This game is fun and made by and indie developer to boot. The gameplay is crisp, fast, and addicting, while still maintaining it's originality and loyalty to it's fan base.The devs are STILL adding new content to the game and tweaking, so while it still has some ways to go, I can't reccomend this enough. Plus, at the time of me writing this (1/27/14) it's on SALE.

If you're an INS fan; buy it. If you're a modern military shooter fan; buy it twice. Once so you can play it, and then the second time so that after you smash your computer, delete your Steam account, and swear off FPSs for the rest of your life because of getting hurt so many times, you come crawling back with your tail in between your legs and beg for more.

See? Told you the game was like my ex-girl friend.

9/10

reviewText: The perfect mix of tactical, realistic FPS gameplay without bringing game pace to a crawl. Teamwork is essential for success in this game. There is next to no HUD; no map, ammo count, killfeed(depending on the server), health indicator, etc. All you are given is the objectives, time, and your magazine count shows up when you reload. Weapons sounds are some of the best that I have heard in a video game, and the guns take skill to control. If you go into this game running and gunning trying to spray everyone down, you're gonna have a bad time. This game is a must have for anyone who enjoys urban, realistic, tactical gameplay.\n\nThe competitive community is fantastic. Most people are more than willing to help out newer players and teams get on their feet if they are interested in the competitive side and it feels like a real community instead of a bunch of teams trying to beat eachother. Everyone is always looking to scrim, get a pick-up game going or just chill in a pub. This game needs to be in your library if you enjoy FPS.

reviewText:
A refreshing FPS with some creative game modes, this has replaced battlefield 4 and CS GO (for me), I'll split the review into pros and cons.

Positive
+Guns have a sense of weight which is missing in alot of FPS.
+Hardcore- no killcams, no killfeed (well most servers) and no bloody hitmarkers
+Good gamemodes, fun and very intense
+There's an offline bot mode
+Lots of maps, as well as, night versions
+Cheap
+You can play fine at pings around 200
+Runs nicely (well mostly)
+Developers give free dlc and are constantly updating and supporting the game
+In game callouts are on point (as you may already know)

Negative
-Population is not massive, but it's not small either, just could be bigger (but you'll easily find a game)
-The offline mode has no proper UI in place in order to change gamemodes and maps (you change it in the console)
-Stuttering and Microstuttering plague the game (different for some)
-Graphics aren't great, but it's pretty easy to run, on a gtx870m, its maxed out at, 1080p, 2xmssa and fxaa, solid 60fps.
-Some weird ♥♥♥ 3rd person animations (I personally like immersion) not all the time, just when people slide and sometimes when sprinting (as if they are air running- feet are slightly above the ground)

8/10- Recommend for anyone who wants to play  a hardcore FPS that's fun with lot's of action and doesn't take realism to the point where combat is as enjoyable as wiping your ♥♥♥ with sandpaper, but isn't so hellbent on making you feel like a special snowflake (e.g. COD).

reviewText:
This game is just....wow. Everything is amazingly accurately depicted, from the grenade weight, the audio, the physics, the bullet penetration going through different materials, the suppressing fire system, everything about this game is intense and punishing if you ♥♥♥♥ up for a second while in a firefight.

It's times like this in a match where you're scoped in, looking to pick off any enemies, especially opposing snipers or grenadiers. You see an enemy sniper far away, and he sees you too. It's all a matter of who pulls the trigger faster, and you hear an empty dull click from your gun. No more bullets loaded in the chamber? You soon find yourself dead.


That's right, there's no ammo counter or anything that indicates how many shots you have left, nor a crosshair or a life bar. The only thing you have on your HUD is how many magazines you have left and a compass w/ a map you can toggle. This game requires good teamwork and communication to win matches, and it's rewarding to blow up the final enemy cache with a brick of C4 when you're the last man standing.

Bottom line: if you want a tactical shooter that delivers intense close quarters combat action, with a variety of huge maps as well, get this game, you will not be disappointed. My only gripe is that I wished the developers spent more time optimizing the game, because it only utilizes less than half of my cpu and gpu combined, which can lead to minor fps drops at times.

Oh, and get ready for all the allahu ackbars" on the mics."

reviewText: I bought this game maybe 6 days ago, and I already have 56 hours of active gameplay on record. This game is THE best first person shooter I have played in awhile. It is completely addicting, and wildely fun. The controls are simple and memorable, no lag, easy voting for maps and other things, as well as a co-op mode which Is amazing to play with friends. The game is just..... amazing.... thats the only word that I can use to describe it, yet that word alone does not do it justice. I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of first person shooters and team based combat... you will NOT regret buying this game.

reviewText:
Update: As of the May 2016 update the game is almost unplayable. In co-op the newest AI is absolutely horrid. It is the worst AI I have ever worked with. They managed to make it even worse than they did with the October 2015 update. There is absolutely no challenge. They run wildly around corners, walking into their own molotovs, or onto frags they just threw. The bots spawn at random intervals, sometimes spawning behind players that have already cleared an area and moved up. It was never this bad until the most recent update. Basic server config tweaks haven't been enough to fix it. It looks like I need to find a way to fix the AI myself. If I can't... Thanks devs, your game is almost dead to me.

The older part of this review still holds true.

Don't get me wrong, I absolutely love this game and I've had plenty of good experiences with it. It's a hardcore, tactical shooter with a huge emphasis on teamwork. Even though it's running on the source engine it's still fairly visually impressive. The player and gun models look good, and some of the particle effects are great. The smoke and dust puffing up through a firefight really add to the experience. The sound design is also worth noting. You really feel like you're there. It's powerful, and at times almost scary. Getting shot at can really be intense. A year and a half ago the experience was great. Everyone playing was interested in playing the objective and knew what to do. If someone needed help learning the game people were willing to give advice. If a troll joined everyone would bash him to the ground and then vote kick. It was just an amazingly fun experience. I would have definitely recommended it.

Unfortunately I can't recommend this game due to some developer decisions. They continue to add more newb friendly" mechanics to the game

reviewText:
Imagine, if you will, that a teenage Battlefield Bad Company 2 took a blushing Counterstrike Source for a ride in its car late one friday evening.

They are driving, some light petting from both parties, they eventually park the car in a secluded place and make tender, tender love... obviously due to their young age niether have thought about protection or possible consequenses of the late evening tryst.

A few months go by and CSS begins to swell, already the cramps and mood swings are evident, at first they could not comprehend the situation but it was soon evident that CSS was going to be a mother. BC2 tries to be supportive but simply could not hold a job in today's economy, owing largely to the short attention spans of modern gamers. CSS's family are furious and blame BC2 for the precarious situation forced upon the lovely CSS.

Eventually the big day come, after much grunting, screaming and perineal tearing, Insurgency is born... A remarkabbly average and underated child, Insurgency grew to be an extremely acceptable youth with hours and hours of fun had by and with all of his friends.

We Salute you Insurgency, continue to grow into the wonderful game that we know you can be...

reviewText:
After over 800 hours and almost a year of play time, I figure it is time to write a review.

I'll keep it short - Even if it is not on sale, it is worth your time.

Pros-
-Competitive scene is growing and inviting (by this I mean that everyone (for the most part) is friendly).  There are several big comp scenes for players, being the ESL (Euro) and DGL (NA), but as far as pick up games go, both are open no matter where you call home, if you don't mind dealing with ping around 150-200.
-I've heard it is pretty realistic.  I have personally never been shot at, but playing Insurgency makes me not want to be shot at.
-Tactical, yet fast paced.  While you have the option to play slow and wait for an enemy to run into you, you don't need to, as a majority of people will play fast or switch up their speed of play.  There are many game modes that cater to the individual's play style.
-Difference in modes.  Want to die and respawn a lot? Play push.  Want to still die but not as much? Play skirmish.  Want to be the last guy up, realizing that your teammates are talking crap about you (and calling you ugly) in the chat you cannot hear while they are dead and you are not?  Then play firefight, elimination, or ambush.
-Lack of Clutter.  Insurgency, by default, has no HUD, no kill indicators, no ammo counts, etc.  It is about as bare bones as it gets.   You have the option of bringing up a small compass now, but it will do you no good when you are getting shot at.  You also need to learn to count bullets, as mags are independant from one another, meaning no bullet cross over.  If you take a couple shots with each mag, then reload, and do that 4 times, you are going to find yourself with half empty bullet holders.
-Great dev support.  The devs are always tweaking things, updating maps, guns, etc.  The game feels different from when I started.

Cons-
-The (making a generalization here, no hate please) community can be a bit childish.  If I had a dollar for every Allahu Akbar" I have heard

reviewText:
TLDR: Buy this if you like Red Orchestra, Counterstrike, and intense gameplay where you actually care about how loud your footsteps are, you'll love this. Intensity comes from interesting spawn ticket system and high-stakes firefights. Also FAL best gun, objectively.

Insurgency started life as a Sourcemod way back in god knows when under the name Insurgency: Modern Infantry Combat. It was a time where Red Orchestra was considered pretty new and fresh, and I remember it actually being one of the first games that I ever saw that had weapon deadzoning involved. It was a slow-speed, long-range, lethal shooter that was set in the very real world of Marines fighting Insurgents in the middle east, probably Iraq.

Now it's simply called Insurgency, and it's changed a lot. The biggest change is the maps are smaller, making it feel much like the bizarre lovechild of Counter-Strike and Red Orchestra. It's a gifted child. Other changes include that the USMC forces are now simple, unnamed Security Forces" which appear to be Security contractors cooperating with Marines under a different name. The Insurgent forces also now have no real-life name attached to them

reviewText:
A fantastic FPS with heavy leanings on stressing realism. First thing to note, the pace of the game and firefights feel just right. Gun mechanics, hit boxes, ballistics, sounds, and maps have all been polished quite nicely. The level of immersion you will feel while playing the game is incredible, and you will be provided with many tense moments while playing. Whether it's the RPG being fired from a distant spot in the map, or the sound of your comrade screaming as he's being shot at, you'll find yourself doing whatever it takes to stay alive because you'll truely fear for your life.

Insurgency doesn't BS you by making you level up guns to unlock attachments. Everyone gets an allocated amount of supply points to modify their loadouts freely, at spawn. Want a optic site? You got one. Want to carry a molotov instead of grenade? You got it. Want heavy armor? Sure. You pick your own loadouts based on your preferences. This adds a tremendous amount of variation in the loadouts that you can create.

Overall, this is one of the better realism FPS shooters. The learning curve for new users can be considered steep, but this makes it all the more satisfying when you do finally get the hang of things. Well worth the price.

reviewText: I think Insurgency is a great game. I like the close quarters combat. I also like the fact that it is objective based, the players are rewarded more for getting objectives than kills. It takes a good team the win, not just people that can get kills. It is more of a hardcore game where you don't have a minimap that shows where the enemy are. You also don't know your health status or your weapons ammo status. The emphasis is not on what rank you are but if you are a team player that communicates well. The game play is intense. Give yourself time to learn the maps. The longer you play the better you will become. It is not a run and gun game, it is tactical. I also like the fact that the system requirements are not to high, the game looks great and it will be able to include more players.

reviewText:
This game is very good and would recommend it to anyone who likes this sort of fps game. Of course there are some bugs which have been encountered by some player (but luckily enough not me, not encountered a single one). I only hope that this game gets a bigger player base and becomes better because of it.

The fact that it doesn't have features such as kill cam or radar or crosshairs just makes it all the more fun imo. Having features like kill-cam ruins the games because it makes it much easier to see where you got killed from. The fact that it doesn't have them means it is slightly harder than normal fps's, but when you get used to it it just becomes easier.

I've also heard that this game requires a fair bit of team communication but from what I have experienced on the servers I have played there has been little or no communication between teams. Obviously it would help players on your team if you do have a mic and use it to communicate.

All in all I would give this game an 8/10 at this moment in time as it has just been released.

reviewText:
This is about the best balance of action-packed and strategic focused FPS that I am aware of.

It doesn't have the large maps and sometimes tedious realism of ARMA and it doesn't have the millions of unlocks, attachments, vehicles and run-and-gun madness of Battlefield.

It is simple, the gameplay isn't perfect, nor is it flashy and it's maps are not big - but it rewards teamwork, good communication and thoughtful play whilst remaining fast paced and full of excitement. The guns feel solid when you fire them and they are deadly when used effectively (any gun can one shot kill). You have limited kit, hud, no killfeed and limited ammo and therefore it takes time to get to grips with the game - and that is the beauty of it. Each decision you make is more important with these limitations and you have to use your head to stay alive.

The community is not quite as vibrant as with the original Insurgency, with less people in total and a lack of competitive play, but it's still good for some exciting games here and there. The game modes lack the tension of the original mod (they are designed to be more fast paced and have shorter game times) and the maps feel less well thought out - but maybe that is just nostalgia. I really liked grinding up the hill at Karkar.

Worth a try if you haven't already.

reviewText:
This game is not CoD.  It is not Counter Strike, nor is it Battle field; however, this game will have you peeking around corners and begging your friends for cover as you cross the street.

I only play the game for the co-op aspect.  I don't play PvP with the exceptions of a few games, so if you are reading this for a review on the PvP multiplayer, I would take this info lightly.

The sounds!  Not that I have ever been in a fire fight, but I feel more like I have now than ever before.  The pop from your weapons and the cracking of bullets ricocheting off rocks will have you, the player, ducking in your seat!  The frantic screams for help that the characters shout while under fire can be extremely dis-concerning.

I feel that  the bullet physics are lacking in comparison to Battle field, but the guns have excellent recoil, and the dust as well as the blur that arise from fully auto fire is lovely.

The AI is decent.  Certainly not the best I've ever seen, but far from the worst.

All and all, if you want an intense co-op fps to play with your friends, I highly recommend this game.  There are TONS of dedicated servers, so finding an empty server for you and your peeps is never a problem.  And the game carries a very fare price tag: $15

Insurgency is really well made first-person shooter with probably the most realistic experiences I've encountered in games. It's different than let's say CS for example, playing Counter-Strike you're aware that it's only a game etc. but here... here YOU are directly in game. There is no minimap or bullet counter, there is no hit markers, when you're being suspended behind your cover by enemy fire, you simply experience being trapped in there. Watch out for yourself and good luck!

Advantages
Stunning graphics, not made to look pretty, made to look realistic
Sounds are really great, you'll understand what I'm talking about when you will hear those bullets flying right next to your nose
Impressive variety of detailed and greatly designed maps. Night modes for most of maps, what is something really nice
Constantly updated content with steam workshop access, what makes game so customisable as almost none other game
Fair price for that kind of game
The most authentic mechanics I've ever encountered
It's literally tactic shooter, not like rush B fast"
date:
but you really need to think tactically to defeat your opponent
Pleasant co-op mode
Disadvantages
Little bit buggy
Probably the most toxic comunitty I have heard in a long time

If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!"

reviewText:
Insurgency is a unique FPS that requires alot of precision and skill. You have no crosshair and no way of knowing how much ammunition is left in your magazine (unless you count how many rounds you have shot).

This game clearly seems to focus on the realistic side of shooters, depending on what sort of body armour you have, it will usually take 4-5 shot to kill someone, also depending on the weapon you are using. Headshots on the other hand are instant kills.

Another great feature about this game that makes it more enjoyable is the community. Many have provided people with additional content e.g Weapon skins or retextures. Others have also made modifications that may suit your requirements if the game itself does not. Overall this game is very enjoyable and is hard not to get addicted to.  9/10 from me

reviewText:
I bought this back in Feb. 2014.  I played it a little here and there for about a month.  Some friends and I were RB6:RVS players about 10 years ago and wanted something challenging like RVS was.  Insurgency was was promising then, but we're  all mid 30's and video games just don't have the priority they did 10 years ago for us.  Insurgency could have used some polishing up.

Fastforward to yesterday, Feb. 21st 2015....

Unknown to us that a update with new playlists was coming, we had decided to give Insurgency a go again.  Wow!  We had a lot of fun.  It's really been refined.  The Firefight 5v5 gametype is suberb so far. I love it.  I think I could even play it without my gaming buddys, which is something of a rarity for me.  Even though I was stuck as a Flanker and didn't have many primary weaopon options, I didn't feel at a major disadvantage.  I assumed I was stuck with the player type nobody wanted, but I was wrong.  5v5 Firefight offers a good balance of players.  There aren't so many that you can't find a way through to an objective, but not so few that you don't consider taking calculated risk.  A good team could control the map with solid team work, but not to the point where luck is a non-factor to the equation.

I think the 5v5 Firefight gametype is my new go-to.

reviewText:
Pros:
-The game makes you tense.
-Guns are well balanced
-Damage model is realistic. It is a two shot kill at the most for every gun. (it's a pro if you like those kind of damage models.)
-Grenade spam is non-existant.
-People work with their team often.
-finding servers is easy.
-When you ADS the scope itself zooms in and not the outside of the scope.
-Game CAN be played on older hardware.
-Nice selection of graphics options.
-HUD is minimal (the only thing that shows up on screen is where the objactives are.
-You must rely on sounds of gun shots and foot steps to out smart your enemy.

Cons:
-Grenades are not very effective it most situations.
-If you do not know the maps you will be killed often.
-Co-op bots are not the greatest sometimes. They can seem to have aimbot. Or just be really stupid.
-Co-op does not give you very many respawns unless you are playing checkpoint.
-Some people can be a jerk to you when you make a bad descision.
-There is no match making that allows you to play with lower skilled players.
-No unlocking weapons or anything like that.
-Graphics are not the greatest as it is running on the source engine.
-Key bindings can sometimes clear themselves and not work when you are rebinding a key, or reopening the game.
Summary:

This game is great overall for the price! Humble Bundle boosted the games popularity and made it so much easier to find servers. i have 23 hours into the game as of this review. and I play this game often! It is a great FPS that beats CoD and Battlefield. My major complaint it there is no skill based match making, as it makes it difficult for new players to get a feel for the games mechanics. Do I reccomend this game? ABSOLUTLY YES!

reviewText:
Simply put: this is the game that EA and DICE tried to make but instead created a flaming pile of horse ♥♥♥♥. Insurgency is the delicious air freshener to cover up the aroma of mistake and disappointment that EA and DICE have created.

This game is literally a Source Engine Battlefield that actually works as a game. Plenty of maps and gamemodes but a map, minimap or health indicator are nowhere to be seen - in fact, the only HUD elements in this game include the CTF-type objectives (just one of many game modes), squad members and a mag count,  that is all . It encourages you to guess where the enemy is and to keep up to date with teammates on the whereabouts of said enemies.

There are a decent amount of weapons to choose from. Instead of getting a weapon for each slot (primary, secondary, explosive etc.), you get equipment tokens (not sure if thats what they are called). They do not cost anything but are reduced everytime you equip a weapon, explosive or attatchment (some equipments are worth more than others, for example, a laser sight uses 4 tokens where as a red dot sight uses 1). If you remove an attatchment, for example, then you get your tokens back.This system is such an effective and streamlined mechanism which, at first, I thought would be a mediocre and half-arsed twist to another FPS title.

To conclude, this game is the greatest alternative to EA's latest installments of Battlefield. Especially since this game isn't £50 and can go as low as £2! It nurtures a community that is not so salty, a rarity in the FPS genre. Just grab it or go and lick the ♥♥♥♥ stain that has been left behind.

You can't go wrong with this one.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I have ever played! I got this game on sale for 2.50$, it's normal price is 17$, but I would have gladly payed 50$ for it. This is a fairly long review, however I've tryed to cover all major aspects of the game, please tell me in the comments if I left something out.

Despite being early access there are little to no glitches and those that are present in the game are not gamebreaking.

The online community is really cool, I haven't met many toxic players at all, people are willing to communicate and use teamwork to capture objectives or to advance. Teamwork, communication and strategy play a big part in this game compared to games like CoD, where everyone kind of goes to do their own thing instead of sticking together and working as a team.

The graphics really aren't that bad and you won't need a 2000$ PC to run it, compared to triple A games like Battlefield and CoD.

There is a cool squad member" selection when picking your loadout. Example: If you choose the Support class

recommended: if you pick the sniper / designated marksman class
hoursPlayed: you will have access to high power scopes

votesTotal: large weapons and grenades will add more weight to you
votesFunny: making you move slower and get exhausted quicker. So players can choose light armor (or no armor) and light guns (or no guns) and rush objectives

column17: monitor a certain area or move to a specific location / objective.\n\nThe HUD is very limited
column18: showing literally nothing but your gun. No crosshair
column19: no health bar
column20: no ammo counter
column22: no killfeed. The only "ammo counter" you have shows you how many mags you have left. If you reload and your magazine still has bullets in it
column23: it goes back to you. Therefore if you tend to reload often
column24: you'll find yourself loading in magazines that are only half full. There IS a map that you can look at by pressing a specific key but no "minimap" like we have in CoD. When you get shot or hurt
column25: the peripheral area of your vision will get blurry
column26: that's the only way to tell when you are hit. Again refering to CoD as an example
column28: not your whole screen and it isn't covered in blood. Also theres no indicator to tell you in which direction you were hit from.\n\nIf everything I've said up to now hasn't convinced you yet

reviewText: While not without some minor faults, Insurgency is really worth the buy. Extremely punishing for people who don't work as a team. One mistake and you're dead, this game is all about teamwork and supporting one another so you can come out on top. There's a great amount of tension within each game, you have to be aware that someone could be waiting around every corner, blitzing through the map and thinking you can take everyone out yourself just won't happen, it's a much slower paced game than other modern warfare multiplayer shooters, but by no means does it mean it's boring. Just watch out for the few elitists that are good at this game and feel the need to berate any 'noobs'.
